property.value: 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 6, Rogers, Arkansas 72758

calculationType.citation: Page 8, late charge provision – “2% of the monthly payment will be assessed as a late charge.”

graceDays.citation: Page 8 – late charge applies if rent not paid by the 10th of the month

secondFeeCalculationType.citation: Page 21 – “late charge in an amount equal to five percent (5%) of such payment.”

secondFeeGrace.citation: Page 21 – no grace period mentioned for the 5% charge

synopsis.value: Leased premises located at 5100 W.J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 602, Rogers, Arkansas, 6th floor; 14,642 usable sq ft and 17,090 rentable sq ft. Primary term of 77 months ending on the last day of the 77th full month, with optional extension to 90 months upon notice within 14 (or 21) days of Commencement. Commencement defined by completion of landlord's work, final inspection, notice, and tenant's furniture installation.

keyParameters.value: Usable Area: 14,642 sf; Rentable Area: 17,090 sf; Primary Term: 77 months; Extension Option: up to 90 months; Commencement Date: after landlord's substantial completion and tenant's notice (see definition).

narrative.value: As indicated by Exhibit A, the Premises consist of approximately 14,642 usable square feet and 17,090 rentable square feet on the 6th floor of the Building. The Primary Term shall end on the last day of the seventy‑seventh (77th) full month, with a tenant right to extend to ninety (90) months by providing notice within fourteen (14) days of the Commencement Date. Commencement occurs after landlord substantially completes tenant improvements, receives final inspection approval, provides notice to tenant, and tenant begins furniture installation within eight (8) business days.

synopsis.value: Landlord pays real property taxes and special assessments; tenant pays taxes on personal property and any excess taxes over the Base Year (2016).

definition.value: "Taxes" means real property taxes and special assessments levied against the Premises, Land, or improvements, and personal property taxes attributable to tenant’s fixtures.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: Calendar year 2016; Tenant may audit tax invoices within 180 days of receipt.

narrative.value: Landlord agrees to pay all real property taxes and special assessments that accrue against the Premises. Property taxes incurred in any year that exceed the taxes on the property during the Base Year (2016) will be passed through to tenants on a pro‑rata basis. Tenant shall be liable for all taxes levied on personal property or fixtures placed in the Premises and shall reimburse Landlord for any such taxes upon demand.

synopsis.value: Operating expenses in excess of the Base Year (2016) are passed through to the Tenant on a pro‑rata basis; controllable expenses capped at 5% annual increase; capital improvements excluded unless they reduce Tenant’s expenses.

definition.value: "Operating Expenses" means all ordinary and reasonable costs incurred by Landlord for ownership, management, maintenance, repair, replacement, restoration or operation of the Building, excluding capital improvements, casualty costs, financing costs, depreciation, leasing commissions, and other excluded items.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: 2016; Pro‑rata share based on rentable square footage; Controllable expense increase cap: 5% per year.

billingTimeline.value: Landlord provides an annual statement of Operating Expenses within 90 days after year‑end; Tenant may review within 90 days of receipt; Additional Rent payable monthly based on estimated increase; final reconciliation within 30 days after annual statement.

formulas.value: Tenant’s Proportionate Share = (Tenant Rentable Sq Ft ÷ Building Total Rentable Sq Ft) × 100%; Additional Rent = Tenant’s Share × (Operating Expenses – Base Year Expenses).

capitalRules.value: Capital improvements are excluded from Operating Expenses unless they directly reduce Tenant’s Operating Expenses, in which case they are amortized over useful life on a straight‑line basis.

narrative.value: Operating expenses incurred in any year that exceed the Operating Expenses on the Building for the Base Year (2016) will be passed through to the Building tenants on a pro‑rata basis. Controllable Operating Expenses shall not increase by more than five percent (5%) annually. Capital improvements are excluded unless they directly reduce Tenant’s Operating Expenses, in which case they are amortized over their useful life.

synopsis.value: Landlord is responsible for structural components, roof, foundation, exterior walls, common areas, and building systems; Tenant responsible for interior maintenance, repairs, and damage caused by its own actions.

narrative.value: Landlord shall make all repairs and replacements to the Building (including roof, foundation, exterior walls, structural components, common areas, grounds, windows, and Building Systems) at its own cost, except for repairs and replacements that Tenant must make under the Lease. Tenant shall maintain the usable Premises in good condition and promptly make necessary repairs, and shall be responsible for damage caused by its negligence or default.

synopsis.value: Tenant may not make alterations, additions or improvements without Landlord’s prior written consent; consent shall not be unreasonably withheld. Tenant must provide drawings and may use Landlord‑approved contractors.
Tenant may install signage per Exhibit E, must comply with building standards and laws; removal and restoration required at lease end; no exterior signage without Landlord’s consent.

Landlord shall provide water, temperature control (heating/air‑conditioning), janitorial services (if requested), electrical lighting, elevator service, and 24/7 electronic key access; additional services may be billed to Tenant.

Landlord maintains building insurance; Tenant must maintain workers’ compensation and commercial general liability (minimum $2M property, $4M per occurrence) and fire/extended coverage for Tenant Improvements; policies name Landlord as additional insured.

keyParameters.value: Tenant Liability Coverage: $2,000,000 property, $4,000,000 per occurrence; Landlord insurance not less than replacement cost.

synopsis.value: If Premises are destroyed or damaged such that repairs cannot be completed within 120 days, Lease terminates and rent is abated; if repairs completed within 120 days, rent is abated proportionally; tenant may terminate if damage exceeds 30% of space.

Each party indemnifies the other for liabilities arising from its own negligence; Tenant indemnifies Landlord for injuries caused by Tenant, and vice‑versa, except for gross negligence of the indemnified party.
Premises to be used only for Tenant’s business offices and lawful purposes; no storage of trucks or vehicles without Landlord consent; compliance with all laws and building rules required.
Landlord may enter Premises with 24‑hour notice for inspection, repairs, or to show to prospective purchasers; may enter without notice in emergencies.

Tenant may assign or sublet to affiliates or any company with net worth ≥ $100,000,000, subject to Landlord’s prior written consent (not unreasonably withheld). If Landlord does not respond within 10 business days, consent is deemed given. Tenant must pay 50% of any rent received above Base Rent to Landlord.

Tenant entitled to at least 4.5 parking spaces per 1,000 rentable sq ft at no charge; Landlord reserves six exclusive spaces for itself; any exclusive spaces granted to other tenants must be matched for Tenant.

If >50% of Premises taken by eminent domain, Lease terminates and rent is abated; if <50% taken, rent reduced proportionally; any compensation awarded belongs to Landlord, except Tenant’s loss of business goodwill.

If Tenant remains in possession after lease expiration, Landlord may deem tenancy month‑to‑month or at sufferance; rent payable is 150% of base rent plus Operating Expenses and Taxes; additional penalties apply after three months.
Tenant shall peacefully and quietly enjoy the Premises provided rent is paid and covenants performed, without hindrance from Landlord.

Tenant default includes failure to pay Base Rent within 5 business days after notice; Landlord may terminate lease, relet, and seek damages including unpaid rent, costs, and liquidated damages; late charge of 5% applies after 2 days past due.
Lease is subordinate to any existing or future mortgages; Tenant will execute non‑disturbance agreements as reasonably requested by mortgagees.
Tenant may not place any lien or encumbrance on the Premises; must promptly notify Landlord of any lien filed against the Premises.
Tenant may not store or use hazardous materials except for limited office supplies; must follow labeling, storage, and disposal standards; tenant responsible for cleanup costs if it causes a spill.

Tenant must comply with all building rules and regulations attached as Exhibit C; includes lock control, directory, signage restrictions, movement of goods, trash disposal, noise, and other conduct standards.
Marshall Saviers with Sage Partners represents Tenant; Tom Allen with Pinnacle Realty Group represents Landlord.
Tenant must deliver an estoppel certificate within 30 days of Landlord’s request, confirming lease terms, rent status, and absence of defaults.

All notices must be delivered personally, by nationally recognized overnight carrier, or certified mail with return receipt to the addresses set forth in the Basic Lease Information; effective upon delivery or carrier record.

Tenant has a right of first refusal on adjacent space on the 6th floor; must notify Landlord within 10 business days of landlord’s receipt of a third‑party offer; lease terms for the space mirror existing lease.
Tenant may expand into First Refusal Space; rent mirrors current rate; Tenant Improvement Allowance prorated at 90% for the remaining term; relocation by Landlord is prohibited.

If Landlord fails to cure a default within 30 days after notice, Tenant may terminate lease, cure the default and offset costs against rent, or pursue other remedies; Landlord not liable for personal obligations beyond the Building ownership.

executiveSummary.value:
**Lease Summary**
Landlord **PH Office 2, LLC** (Rogers, AR) leases to **Bayer HealthCare LLC** (Whippany, NJ) approximately **17,090  rentable sf** (14,642  usable sf) on the 6th floor of 5100 W.J.B. Hunt Drive, Rogers, AR. The primary term is 77 months, commencing after completion of tenant improvements and issuance of certificates; rent starts on the first day of the 6th month at **$24.50 / RSF** (incl. taxes, utilities, insurance) and escalates 2 % annually to **$27.05 / RSF** by month 66‑77 (see rent schedule). Tenant may extend to **90 months** (notice 14 days) and holds two **5‑year renewal options** (notice 180‑365 days). Landlord provides a **Tenant‑Improvement Allowance** of **$72.22 / RSF** (≈$1.23 M); if extended to 90 months the allowance rises to **$84.42 / RSF** (≈$1.44 M). Parking is **4.5 spaces per 1,000 RSF** at no charge. Tenant is responsible for interior repairs, janitorial (optional), and utilities; Landlord maintains structural components and building systems. Early termination is permitted at month 51 with six‑month notice, requiring reimbursement of the un‑amortized TI allowance and broker commission (7 % interest). The lease includes standard insurance, operating‑expense pass‑throughs, subletting rights, hold‑over penalties, and a right of first refusal on adjacent space.

audit_items.issue_description: Lease Date is shown as "_`--5. 2015" which is partially illegible and may be mis‑read.
audit_items.affected_clause: Lease Date (Basic Lease Information)
audit_items.recommended_action: Verify the exact lease execution date from the original signed document.

audit_items.issue_description: Security Deposit field is marked as "Intentionally Deleted" with no amount provided.
audit_items.affected_clause: Security Deposit (Section 2 – Base Rent and Security Deposit)
audit_items.recommended_action: Confirm whether a security deposit is required, and if so, obtain the agreed amount and insert it into the lease.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit D (Memorandum of Acceptance of Delivery) lacks critical numeric data: Possession Date, rentable square footage, proportionate share percentage, and early termination dates are blank.
audit_items.affected_clause: Exhibit D – Memorandum of Acceptance of Delivery of Premises
audit_items.recommended_action: Complete Exhibit D with the missing values before lease execution or amendment.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit A (Premises description) references area on Exhibit A but the actual square footage details are only partially repeated in the main text; the exhibit itself is not provided.
audit_items.affected_clause: Premises description (Section 1 – Premises and Term)
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach a finalized Exhibit A showing the exact rentable and usable square footage and floor plan.

audit_items.issue_description: Base Rent table shows $0.00 for months 1‑5, contradicting the narrative that Base Rent begins on the first day of the sixth full month.
audit_items.affected_clause: Base Rent schedule (Table 1) vs. Rent Commencement description
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify whether rent is truly $0 for months 1‑5 or if prorated rent applies; amend either the table or the narrative for consistency.

audit_items.issue_description: Late charge provision appears twice with different percentages: 2% in Section 2 and 5% in Section 21 (Events of Default).
audit_items.affected_clause: Late charge clause (Section 2 – Base Rent) and Section 21 – Remedies
audit_items.recommended_action: Reconcile the late charge percentage to a single, unambiguous amount.

audit_items.issue_description: Basic Lease Information states it controls in case of conflict, yet later the Lease Agreement contains differing definitions for "Primary Term" and renewal options that could conflict with the Basic Lease Information.
audit_items.affected_clause: Conflict resolution clause (Section 4 of Basic Lease Information) vs. detailed Primary Term provisions (Section 5 – Premises and Term)
audit_items.recommended_action: Perform a clause‑by‑clause comparison and explicitly resolve any inconsistencies; consider inserting a clarification clause.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord's reasonable judgment" for temperature control and "reasonable and good‑faith determination" of Option Rent introduce uncertainty about service levels and rent adjustments.
audit_items.affected_clause: Temperature Control (Section 9 – Services) and Option Rent Notice (Section 5 – Primary Term and Renewal Options)
audit_items.recommended_action: Define objective criteria or measurement standards for these judgments, or require written confirmation from both parties.

audit_items.issue_description: Multiple clauses rely on "reasonable" actions (e.g., reasonable effort to cure defaults, reasonable consent for contractors, reasonable adjustments to temperature control).
audit_items.affected_clause: Default cure periods (Section 20 – Events of Default), Contractor approval (Section 7 – Alterations), Temperature control overrides (Section 9 – Services)
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert specific time frames, performance metrics, or approval processes to replace vague “reasonable” language.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant Improvement Allowance is capped at $72.22/RSF for the primary term and $84.42/RSF if term is extended, but the lease states Tenant is responsible for all costs in excess of the allowance without a defined cap, exposing Tenant to unlimited overruns.
audit_items.affected_clause: Tenant Improvements (Section 6 – Tenant Improvements)
audit_items.recommended_action: Negotiate a maximum cap on excess costs or require landlord to share overruns above a certain threshold.

audit_items.issue_description: Early Termination fee calculation references “unamortized Improvement Allowance and Broker's commission” with an annual interest rate of 7% but does not specify the method of amortization or the exact commission amount.
audit_items.affected_clause: Early Termination (Section 7 – Early Termination)
audit_items.recommended_action: Obtain the exact broker commission figure and define the amortization schedule for the improvement allowance.

audit_items.issue_description: Operating Expense cap of 5% annual increase is stated, yet the definition of “Controllable Operating Expenses” excludes many items, potentially allowing landlord to allocate large non‑controllable costs to the tenant.
audit_items.affected_clause: Operating Expenses (Section 4 – Operating Expenses)
audit_items.recommended_action: Request a detailed breakdown of controllable vs. non‑controllable expenses and consider adding a cap on total expense pass‑through.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit C (Rules and Regulations) is referenced but not fully provided; key rules affecting tenant operations (e.g., signage, lock changes) are missing.
audit_items.affected_clause: Rules and Regulations (Exhibit C)
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach the complete Exhibit C to the lease file.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant’s right to extend the Primary Term to 90 months requires notice within 14 days of Commencement Date (Section 3 – Primary Term), but later renewal options require notice 180‑365 days before expiration, creating potentially conflicting notice periods.
audit_items.affected_clause: Extension to 90 months (Section 3 – Primary Term) vs. Renewal Options (Section 5 – Primary Term and Renewal Options)
audit_items.recommended_action: Align notice periods for extensions and renewals or clarify which provision takes precedence.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall have the right to enter the Premises at any time without notice in case of emergency" – definition of "emergency" is not specified, potentially allowing frequent unannounced entries.
audit_items.affected_clause: Landlord entry rights (Section 14 – Inspection)
audit_items.recommended_action: Define what constitutes an emergency or require a written justification after entry.

audit_items.issue_description: First Right of Refusal (Section 30) includes a pro‑rated Tenant Improvement Allowance calculation that depends on an example but lacks a formula for other scenarios, creating uncertainty in cost estimation for expansion.
audit_items.affected_clause: First Right of Refusal (Section 30 – Right of First Refusal/Initial Growth)
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert a clear formula for the pro‑rated allowance applicable to any expansion timing.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 33 – Landlord Default / Right of Offset states Tenant may offset amounts only after Landlord fails to cure, yet Section 21 – Remedies allows Landlord to terminate without offset, potentially limiting Tenant’s remedy.
audit_items.affected_clause: Landlord Default remedies (Section 33) vs. Tenant remedies (Section 21)
audit_items.recommended_action: Harmonize default remedies to ensure Tenant’s right to offset is preserved.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit B – Tenant Improvements is noted as "To be added upon approval of Tenant's Plans" but no plan details or cost schedule are attached.
audit_items.affected_clause: Exhibit B – Tenant Improvements
audit_items.recommended_action: Obtain and attach the finalized tenant improvement plans and associated cost schedule.

audit_items.issue_description: "Reasonable" and "good‑faith" language appears throughout (e.g., reasonable consent for contractors, good‑faith determination of rent adjustments), creating potential disputes over interpretation.
audit_items.affected_clause: Multiple sections (e.g., Sections 5, 7, 9, 15, 21)
audit_items.recommended_action: Add definitional clauses or objective standards for these terms.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant is required to pay 50% of any rent received from a subtenant that exceeds Base Rent, but the calculation method and timing of payment are not specified.
audit_items.affected_clause: Assignment and Subletting (Section 15 – Assignment and Subletting)
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify the reporting, calculation, and payment schedule for excess sublease rent.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit A, B, C, D, E are referenced but only placeholders or titles are present; the substantive content of these exhibits is absent.
audit_items.affected_clause: Exhibits list (Section 30 – Exhibit List)
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach complete copies of all referenced exhibits before finalizing the lease.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall have the right to waive any one or more of these Rules and Regulations for the benefit of any particular tenant" – no limitation on frequency or scope of waivers, potentially leading to inconsistent application.
audit_items.affected_clause: Rules and Regulations waiver provision (Section 36 – Rules and Regulations)
audit_items.recommended_action: Add a waiver limitation clause (e.g., written amendment, maximum number of waivers per year).

audit_items.issue_description: Parking allocation is described as "not less than four and one half (4.5) parking spaces per 1,000 rentable square feet" with no mechanism for rounding or actual space assignment, which could affect tenant’s parking availability.
audit_items.affected_clause: Parking (Section 16 – Parking)
audit_items.recommended_action: Define rounding rules and provide a schedule of actual parking spaces assigned to the tenant.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 31 – Quiet Enjoyment guarantees peaceful possession, yet Section 18 – Holding Over allows landlord to create a month‑to‑month tenancy and charge 150% of rent, potentially undermining quiet enjoyment.
audit_items.affected_clause: Quiet Enjoyment (Section 19) vs. Holding Over (Section 18)
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify the rights and remedies during holdover periods to ensure they do not conflict with quiet enjoyment guarantees.
